Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, COMSATS University Islamabad Wah Campus Pakistan Energy management techniques have been immensely adopted in residential, industrial, and commercial sectors to meritoriously flatten the load profile of consumers. In this article, a cutting-edge intelligent energy management system is proposed to analytically monitor and regulate the load demand of a residential area to meritoriously address the load balancing and scheduling optimization problem with an aim to design an autonomous domestic complex, less reliant on the focal power grid. To do so, single- and multi- objective functions are defined for the presented double-layered framework. In the first layer, a day-ahead scheduling problem is evaluated to achieve the mutual revenue of electricity utilities and consumers, while in the second layer, a real-time coordination scheme for robust energy transactions among appliances, multiple microgrids, and the main power system is examined. Herein, a 0 − 1 multiple knapsack problem incorporated with the mixed-integer linear programming method is used to formulate the system mathematical model. To evaluate the intended system model, three heuristic algorithms (genetic algorithm, wind-driven optimization, and their hybrid) are modified. Furthermore, the Monte–Carlo simulations are performed to mitigate the impact of randomness and avoid pre-convergence. From the results of extensive simulations, it is corroborated that the proposed methodology is robust, reliable, and eco-social compared to prior schemes. This article reveals that the hybrid approach outperformed the other two strategies in terms of energy consumption, electricity cost, peak-to-average ratio, and user comfort level. Keywords Demand response Microgrid Genetic algorithm Wind-driven optimization 0 – 1 Multiple knapsack problems Mixed-integer linear programming Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Despite gigantic innovations over the past two decades, more than a billion people, predominantly in Asia, Africa, and Latin America, are unable to access electricity and spend their lives in obscurity, while others have sporadic access marred by recurrent outages [1]. The ultimate goals of global revolutionary policies in the power systems are to facilitate consumers (residential, commercial, and industrial) at a wider scale, boost the domestic economy, and reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions [2]. In orthodox power grids, power generation plants were installed far from populated areas, leading to large power losses in long-distance transmission networks. For this reason - electrical researchers and engineers have been attempting to find alternative and remote sources for electricity generation [1]. In power system studies, decentralization, decarbonization, and digitalization are the three key drivers in power system modernization [3]. In particular, the decentralization is comprised of various distributed generation (DG) units, constructed on both non-dispatchable generators (diesel generator (DiG), micro-turbine (MT), and gas engine (GE)) and dispatchable renewable energy plants (photovoltaic (PV), wind turbine (WT), biomass, and fuel cell (FC)) [4]. In the present era, renewable energy sources (RESs) have been widely adopted due to their socio-economic benefits which have significantly supported the enablers of decentralization and decarbonization [4,5]. Furthermore, the microgrid (MG) is an emerging autonomous low and/or medium voltage generating unit that is constituted of distributed energy resources (DERs) and storage systems (power reservoirs, energy storage banks (ESBs), and electric vehicles (EV)) with limited advanced digital sensing capabilities and high computational efficiency [6], illustrated in Fig. 1. MGs are allocated in close proximity to energy consumers to feed remote residential users and small business communities. In grid-connected mode, it is synchronized with the focal power grid through the point of common coupling (POCC) to ensure the grid’s resilience, however, switches to island mode in case of disturbances and faults [7]. Smart grid (SG) epitomizes an unprecedented opportunity in the avant-garde power industry. For instance, large-scale integration of RESs, distributed ESBs, decentralized transmission and distribution sectors, self-healing and fast restoration technologies, pecuniary rewards for both power consumers and utilities, electric mobility, and digitalization [2,4]. Moreover, demand-side management (DSM) is one of the indispensable aspects of SG which maintain equilibrium between load demand and power delivery. Two integral operations of the DSM approach are load management (LM) and demand response (DR) programs, which are applied to optimize power consumption, reduce electricity bills and peak-to-average ratio (PAR), and enhance the grid’s reliability and flexibility [8]. Through DSM schemes, SG enables residential users to adjust their power consumption patterns through energy management systems (EMSs) that are integrated with DR policies offered by power utilities [9,10]. Some of the key challenges and prevalent operational research areas include cost-effective models for the optimization of power consumption patterns by taking into consideration preferences and comfort levels of electricity users, efficient forecasting prototypes for RES-based power generation and users’ load demand, and optimal integration of storage components and EVs [2,11]. In the successive part, the succinct literature covering the most recent and highly-cited published articles related to day-ahead scheduling and real-time coordination optimization problems is studied and summarized. 1.1 Literature review Although extensive research has been conducted on energy grid renovations, there are still many research questions that need to be answered regarding the major energy dilemmas. More peculiarly, the development of the socio-economic LM methodology for grid stabilization and adaptation has not yet been addressed. Provisional to contemporary trends, the smart EMS design aided with DR stratagem for smart domestic cities is one of the crucial topics in power grid optimization problems [7,12]. To date, various domestic EMSs have been proposed to solve power management problems through decision-making tools, which are based on mathematical modeling and algorithmic approaches [8,13]. The computational complexity that escalates with the optimization problem’s size is the main drawback of such methods. In the literature, various mathematical optimization techniques have captured great attention over the past few years in all subjects of quantitative research that embroil linear or non-linear single- and/or multi- objective functions with diverse constraints [12,13]. Some of the most frequently employed techniques for power scheduling problems are mixed-integer programming (MIP), linear programming (LP), mixed-integer linear programming (MILP), non-linear programming (NLP), mixed-integer non-linear programming (MINLP), and dynamic programming (DP) [6,14], [9,15], [16,17]. On the other hand, nature-inspired heuristic algorithms are the prime choice of decision-makers that have been broadly implemented to overcome computational issues in real-world optimization problems because of their low computational complexity, ease of implementation, self-optimization, and self-healing properties, however, the risk of pre-convergence is a challenging issue here [8,18]. To circumvent these shortcomings, a cooperative scheme must be adopted, therefore, a joint method is proposed in this work based on 0 − 1 multiple knapsack problems (MKP) and MILP techniques, while heuristic algorithms are modified to elucidate designed multi- and single- objective functions for day-ahead load scheduling and real-time coordination problem. Owing to the prodigious significance of DSM programs in residential power management for sustainable smart cities and societies, several studies have been introduced to hedge against precarious issues in energy systems. To highlight the quantity of literature on power scheduling problems associated with keywords (MKP, MILP, heuristic algorithms, and EMSs) within the search period from 2015 to 2022, we explored the Google Scholar database and find that more than 13000 articles have been published till now. Due to lack of space, the authors nominated the 25 most pertinent papers after meticulous skimming for the sake of comparison between proposed and benchmark EMS models. Being with [9], the DR program is proposed to solve the non-convex or NP-hard optimization problem at low computational costs. The authors have designed a system model for the smart home EMS via an effective heuristic approach, based on the gradient-based particle swarm optimization (PSO) to reduce the electricity bills of residential users by optimizing the energy consumption patterns. Sheikhi et al. in [19] introduced an interactive model for a fully automated EMS between electricity and natural gas plants in distribution systems to facilitate residential customers. The presented EMS is founded on a reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm in order to enhance consumers’ participation in DSM programs for peak load reduction in multi-energy networks and electricity bill minimization for residential customers. Furthermore, a comparative performance evaluation for the suggested model of the smart home EM controller is discussed in [2]. The mathematical modeling has been done using both MILP and binary MKP approaches, whereas, three heuristic algorithms: genetic algorithm (GA), binary PSO (BPSO), and ant colony optimization (ACO) are modified to elucidate the recommended architecture of residential EMS. GA-based EMS acts significantly beneficial to achieve objectives of electricity bill reduction, PAR ratio minimization, and user comfort level maximization as compared to others. In [15], a strategy constituted on the interval number optimization is represented to deal with the household appliance scheduling problem by taking into account uncertainties associated with the hot water demand and ambient temperature. The BPSO combined with the MILP technique is adopted for the demonstration of the proposed method’s flexibility in terms of fluctuating consumer demands and uncertainties. Another article [20] studied and analyzed the scheduling problem related to electric load associated with the intelligent home EMS. The proposed methodology is solved by using swarm-based heuristic algorithms such as elephant herding optimization (EHO) and enhanced differential evolution (EDE). It is clear that the EHO technique is quite efficient in scheduling problems as compared to EDE with the waiting time reduction for the improvement in user comfort level. [21] formulated a robust EMS framework for residential smart homes to minimize electricity bills and PAR. The designed controllers are established on four heuristic algorithms (bacterial foraging optimization algorithm (BFOA), GA, BPSO, and wind-driven optimization (WDO)) in the real-time pricing (RTP) environment. The authors reconnoitered unit commitment (UC) and economic dispatch (ED) problems for the MGs’ EMS by adopting the enhanced MILP method, whereas, the formulated scheme is evaluated by a GA-based optimizer to test the functionality of each method [16]. A state-of-the-art home EMS is scrutinized to achieve objectives of the electricity cost and PAR ratio reduction as well as user comfort level maximization. The proposed DP-based scheduling technique is elucidated through the hybrid bacteria foraging and harmony search (HBH) algorithm [17]. Moreover, an integrated hybrid approach consisting of GA and PSO algorithms is structured to optimize the adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference systems (ANFIS) for the short-term wind power-based MGs to plan efficient power systems operations by ensuring power supply reliability. The recommended model is compared with whale optimization algorithm (WOA), water cycle algorithm (WCA), and moth-flame optimizer (MFO) in order to illustrate the performance analysis in [22]. An EA-based optimization framework is analyzed in [23] to implement an interactive DR strategy on the uncertain device loads in SGs for the adjustment of the peak demand while ensuring the power grid network reliability. A cost-effective EMS is anticipated in [24] for the optimal scheduling of residential appliances by employing a hybrid approach based on bird swarm optimization (BSO) and cuckoo search optimization (CSO) algorithms to fulfill multi-objective solution related to the shifting of the electricity load according to the pre-defined objective load curve and improve the user comfort level. In another work, a heuristic-based methodology for the smart EMS is developed in [25] to minimize power consumption and electricity cost. The proposed strategy is designed by applying the GA by taking into account factors of renewable energy availability as well as the comfort level of electricity consumers at the low computational time. [26] employed artificial bee colony (ABC), WDO, and gravitational search algorithms (GSA) to evaluate the optimal power flow (OPF) problem with the objectives of reduction in voltage deviation, active power loss, and fuel cost at a low computational burden. The authors in [27] addressed the scheduling problem of smart residential multi-energy hubs considering the uncertainties related to market prices, load demands, and solar radiation through a risk-constrained two-stage stochastic programming (SP) model. Aslam et al. presented an intelligent EMS model in [12] to manage domestic power consumption by alleviating the PAR and mitigating the electricity bill along with maximization of user comfort through EDE and artificial neural network (ANN). The authors inspected real-world load scheduling problems for smart homes in [28] by employing the meta-heuristic optimization dragonfly algorithm (DA) to achieve minimum electricity cost with a tolerable waiting time while reducing the PAR. A grey wolf optimization (GWO)-based framework for the smart residential scheduler is proposed in [29] to estimate user preferences, whereas, rooftop PV panels with storage systems were installed for the operational cost reduction and home-to-grid (H2G) power exchange programs are included for home EMS. Dinh et al. proposed an EMS architecture to control and schedule electric load in a smart home equipped with RES and ESB units in [30] for the minimization of electricity utilization from the main power grid to facilitate both electricity consumers and power utilities. The EMS framework is based on PSO and BPSO which has dropped energy costs significantly. Alshammari and Asumadu implemented harmony Search (HS), jaya algorithm (JA), and PSO algorithms in [31] for the optimal sizing of a hybrid RES (containing a set of the Wind–PV–Biomass–Battery technologies) with an aim of cost-effective, efficient, and reliable system to meet customers’ electricity demands. An eco-social EMS is studied in [32] to evaluate the grid network’s ability for energy trading schemes via multi-objective PSO with the goal of low electricity costs, high renewable energy usage, and low GHG emission. [33] discussed the impact of uncertainties associated with RES and energy markets as a direct factor during the hybrid MGs scheduling problem by applying the chance-constrained programming (CCP) technique for the reduction in expected operation cost to achieve economic benefits. Hossain et al. in [8] investigated the EMS model for real-time load scheduling schemes by using modified PSO (MPSO) for the grid-connected MG to minimize the operating cost of a small-scale power system under uncertain environments. An effective optimization approach is suggested in [14] which is based on the MIP approach to maximize the MG’s profit while minimizing the risk in profit (RIP) in the presence of DR programs with a significant reduction in the risk percentage. A day-ahead stochastic load scheduling model is designed in [34] for the optimal EM of RES-based MGs while the hydrogen energy storage (HES) system is used to alleviate the RES intermittences with an aim to dynamically balance the energy via Autoregressive integrated moving average technique (ARIMA) and fast forward selection (FFS) methods. In [35], a hybrid RES-based MG that combines multiple renewable resources with storage and backup systems is formulated to meet load requirements at the lowest cost and highest reliability level. The artificial bee colony (ABC) method is modified to minimize the operational cost at a low computational burden. 1.2 Motivation and contributions From reviewed literature, it can be inferred that there are many critical research gaps that need to be addressed for the swift development of the modern power grid. Our motivation behind the presented intelligent IEMS (IEMS) for a smart residential area is subjected to three decisive points: (1.) With the emergence of dynamic tariff rate models and ample smart home appliances innovations, it is practically impossible to manually monitor and schedule the electric load, thus, an IEMS becomes a necessity for the comfortable lifestyle of electricity users [10,36]. In IEMS, the load categorization mechanism permits the scheduler to estimate the influence of each appliance on hourly energy consumption patterns. Furthermore, the IEMS also facilitates prosumers to make cost-effective decisions concerning the charging and discharging of storage units driven by RES power. (2.) For the mathematical modeling, the deterministic methodology (also recognized as the risk-free method) has been adopted to analytically describe the NP-hard combinatorial nature of load scheduling problems [15,37]. An amalgamation of 0 − 1 MKP and MILP approach is used for mathematical formulations of our objective functions. (3.) It is a perilous task for power operators to evaluate large-scale multi-dimensional scheduling problems. In literature, such complete NP-hard problems are frequently evaluated by using heuristic algorithms [30]. Inspired by quantified properties and the NP-hard nature of our optimization problem, three heuristics algorithms are modified in this paper for the validation of the proposed system model. In this paper, a novel double-layer IEMS is proposed for smart residential areas to enhance user comfort levels. Our main contributions are as follows: • First-layer of the proposed system model of IEMS deals with the scheduling optimization problem to minimize PAR and energy consumption bills, while, the second-layer maximizes the user comfort level and also empowers prosumers to participate in DR programs through the real-time coordination problem. • The multi-objective function is constructed on 0 − 1 MKP in combination with the MILP for the scheduling problem formulation, whereas, the single-objective function is designed for real-time rescheduling problems. • The proposed framework is elucidated by GA, WDO, and their hybrid (HGW) algorithms for performance evaluations of our system model, while monte-carlo simulations (MCS) is employed to mitigate the randomness in solutions. Table 1 comparatively highlights the key points (system model, technique, problem, achievement, and drawback) of studied articles and our article. To the best author’s knowledge, the proposed double-layer IEMS model based on single- and multi- objective functions for the day-ahead and real-time scenarios, concurrently is an exceptional notion that is not explored by any other researcher in a presented perspective till now. 1.3 Structure of paper This paper is structured as Section 2 describes the proposed system model, Section 3 presents the problem formulations, Section 4 articulates the proposed methodology, and Section 5 extensively analyzes the simulation results. In the end, the conclusion and future recommendations are stated in Section 6. 2 Proposed system model In this section, the proposed system model for the distributed power system is described. Fig. 2 depicts the generalized architecture that is comprised of n radial feeders. Each feeder has its own micro-source power generation units such as DiGs, PV arrays, WT farms, and MTs with local load controllers (LCs) and advanced communication systems for bi-directional information and power flow. Feeders 1 and 2 feed sensitive loads, while other feeders are used to deliver electricity to traditional loads as per instructions from the focal power grid. Besides it, the static switch (SS) is employed to disconnect feeders 1 or 2 from the main power grid’s controller in the case of contingencies. Furthermore, the surplus power is charged in storage units to meet the power demand for a specified time period. The charger controller of ESBs is linked with MGs and prevents battery overcharging conditions by monitoring the battery’s depth of discharge limits. The IEMS is a computer-aided tool for electricity consumers to monitor, control, and optimize their energy consumption patterns, one of the necessities for smart residential users of the present era [7]. In our smart residential model, each smart home is equipped with smart appliances, SECO, rooftop-PV panel, and sophisticated communication technologies as in Fig. 3. Herein, H smart homes are considered that are coupled with a local MG through a power distribution unit (PDU). In MGs, some of the commonly used communication networks are wide area networks (WANs), neighborhood area networks (NANs), and home area networks (HAN) for the simplex or duplex data flow mechanisms [26]. Fig. 4 illustrates the symbolic representation of the projected IEMS model. It is clear that power utility companies and smart homes are two main drivers that operate in cooperation for their mutual benefit. The SG’s utility interacts with its control room to obtain real-time data related to the operational mode of each MG by collaborating with its MG’s control room. In the MG standalone mode (when the POCC acts as an open switch), the power utility of a particular MG becomes functional and autonomously provides services to a specific remote area. In this scenario, each prosumer is armed with rooftop-PV arrays with a storage system in order to monitor solar panel power through an installed hybrid inverter. The MG’s control room decides how much power will be supplied to the electric load of the smart home based on SECO’s instructions. The electricity user inputs all the pre-defined data such as load parameters interrupts, and time of use (ToU) tariff rates through the user interface. All the gathered data is then dispatched to smart meters (SMs) using the HAN network which is injected into the analyzer for further processing. After data analysis in the analyzer, the refined and categorized data is injected into the energy scheduler (ES) where modified heuristic algorithms solve formulated multi- and single- objective functions. In the day-ahead scheduling problem, input parameters are tariff rate and selected appliances, whereas, in the real-time coordination problem, the process of rescheduling can be executed at any time of the day (whenever the user generates a run-time interrupt). On a larger scale, advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) permits various SMs to synchronize with the MG’s control room through NAN for the sake of power trading among multiple MG and main power grids. 3 Problem formulation For the problem formulation, 0 − 1 MKP and MILP techniques are utilized to define mathematical equations for both scheduling and real-time coordination problems. In our model, a day is taken as a time horizon which is further divided into time slots and expressed as T = [ t 1 , t 2 , t 3 , … , t D ] . 3.1 Load categorization The load categorization is one of the most imperative phases in EMSs applied to classify M smart appliances in a set A = [ a 1 , a 2 , a 3 , … , a M ] based on their operational modes and user’s preferences. In our work, all the electric households are grouped into unschedulable, shiftable, interruptible, and thermal appliances [2,38], a brief explanation for each group is as follows: 1. Unschedulable appliances These are sensitive loads and cannot be scheduled (their length of operation ℓ must be satisfied) in any situation. Hospital load, illumination systems, fans, refrigerators, etc are some of its examples. Must-ran appliances set is represented by U = [ u 1 , u 2 , u 3 , … , u M ] , power rating by ρ u m , and operational state by ψ . Then, the net power consumed in each time slot is calculated by, (1) υ U = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = 1 D ρ u m × ψ ( u m , t d ) Here, υ U indicates cumulative consumed power and ψ ( u m , t d ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] denotes the status of each appliance in U . 2. Shiftable appliances These are manageable appliances that can be shifted at any time without interruptions in their operational time. Washing machines, cloth dryers, dishwashers, etc are examples. Its set is S = [ s 1 , s 2 , s 3 , … , s M ] , power rating is ρ s m , and operational interval is defined by pre-set start time α s m and end time β s m such as α s m ≤ Γ s m ≤ β s m . The total power consumption is, (2) κ S = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = 1 D ρ s m × ψ ( s m , t d ) Here, κ S symbolizes aggregated power consumption and ψ ( s m , t d ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] represents status of each appliance in S . 3. Interruptible appliances These appliances can be scheduled and interrupted by end-users at any time without altering their load profile. Some of the interruptible appliances are coffee makers, ovens, electric kettles, etc. Its set is articulated by I = [ i 1 , i 2 , i 3 , … , i M ] , power rating is symbolized by ρ i m , and operational interval is α i m ≤ Γ i m ≤ β i m . The following equation can be used to find aggregated power consumption, (3) χ I = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = α i m β i m ρ i m × ψ ( i m , t d ) Here, χ I is the net consumed power and ψ ( i m , t d ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] depicts each appliance status. 4. Thermal appliances Electric water heater (EWH), electric space heater (ESH), and electric air conditioner (EAC) are thermal loads that are contributing about 40 % 50 % in the residential load [15]. Such appliances can be controllable in terms of operational time and power consumption profile. The set of thermal appliances is W = [ w 1 , w 2 , w 3 , … , w M ] , power rating is ρ w m , and operational time is given as α w m ≤ Γ w m ≤ β w m . Then, their overall power consumption is, (4) ω W = λ w [ ∑ w = 1 M ∑ d = α w β w ρ w m × ψ ( w m , t d ) ] Here, ω W signifies power consumed by W , λ w shows thermostat levels, and ψ ( w m , t d ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] is the state of each appliance in W . According to load categorization, the gross energy demand E τ by A in a day is determined by, (5) E τ = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = 1 D E ( a m , t d ) = υ U + κ S + χ I + ω W 3.2 Distributed power generation The technical and economic features of PV-based power plants and thermal generation units are discussed here. 1. Solar panel and EBS The escalating trend in the expansion of PV-based technology is created due to the gradual drop in the installation cost of PV panels that have been globally observed over the last fifteen years [12]. In developed countries, the rooftop PV-based MG has conquered exponential popularity in residential complexes [16]. According to [39], the cumulative capacity of solar energy is expected to rise by 1 GW in numerous countries around the ecosphere. An aggregated amount of 629 GW was installed worldwide till the end of 2019. In the period 2016 to 2019, China, the United States (U.S.), Japan, India, and the United Kingdom (U.K) are the top installers of solar panels. However, it is unrealistic to achieve 100% off-grid solar energy owing to its volatile nature and unpredictable weather conditions [2]. In IEMS, a rooftop-PV MG is considered for each smart home. Prosumers harvest their own active power from PV arrays to feed a portion of their electric load. The aggregated PV output E ħ ( t d ) is dependent on installed panel’s area A ħ ( m 2 ) , solar irradiation I r ( kW / m 2 ) , and ambient temperature ( T p ° C ) and calculated by, (6) E ħ ( t d ) = η ħ × A ħ × I r ( t d ) × ( 1 − 0 . 0062 ( T p ( t d ) − 25 ) ) where η ħ , 0.0062, and 25 ( ° C ) are the PV panel’s efficiency, temperature correction factor, and standard room temperature, respectively. Furthermore, E ħ is also reliant on the intensity of the solar radiation (varies with time), the direction of solar arrays, and the type of PV plate [2]. When the amount of harvested power is larger than load demand, the surplus power is indicated by the − v e sign and stored in ESBs (either to further reduce the consumer’s electricity bill or sold back to the focal power grid under pre-defined agreements and policies). The storage unit must be applied with each PV panel to hedge against ambiguous weather and power gaps between supply and demand. The cumulative energy storage E δ is estimated by following equations [12]. (7) E δ ( t d ) = E δ ( t d − 1 ) + λ d × η δ × E δ c h ( t d ) − λ d × E δ d c h ( t d ) η δ Subject to: (7a) E δ c h ( t d ) ≤ E δ c h u p ∀ t d ∈ T (7b) E δ d c h ( t d ) ≤ E δ d c h l o ∀ t d ∈ T (7c) E δ ( t d ) ≤ E δ c h u p ∀ t d ∈ T Here, λ d , η δ , E δ c h , and E δ d c h are time period, efficiency, charging energy, and discharging energy, respectively. Herein, three rudimentary constraints (7a)–(7c) are defined for the battery’s maintenance (or life span), dis/charging capacities, and charging rate. Moreover, E δ c h u p is the charging energy upper limit, E δ d c h l o is the discharging energy lower limit, and E δ c h u p shows upper limit on the stored energy. 2. Thermal generation unit The fuel consumption cost for the thermal generation unit has been frequently articulated as a quadratic polynomial function [2] and given by (8) F g n ( P g n ) = a g n 2 P g n 2 + b g n P g n + c g n where P g n ( MW ) , F g n ( P g n ) ( $ / h ), and a g n ( $ / h ) , b g n ( $ / MWh ) , c g n ( $ / MW 2 h ) are thermal unit active power, fuel cost, and fuel cost coefficients. If the DiGs set is epitomized by G = [ g 1 , g 2 , g 3 , … , g N ] , then the net fuel consumption cost F T is, (9) F T = ∑ n = 1 N F g n ( P g n ) 3.3 PAR It is the ratio of maximum power consumed in a specified time slot to its average aggregated load over a scheduling horizon. The power utility analyzes the PAR curves to study the consumer’s energy consumption patterns for the management and utilization of peak power plants [12]. At high PAR, the power grid’s stability will be at risk which may upsurge the cost of electricity. On the other hand, for the grid’s stability and electricity cost reduction, the level of PAR must be kept low. Therefore, it is highly beneficial for both utilities and consumers to shrink PAR curves in order to maintain a balance between power supply and demand. In our model, the PAR is symbolized by ϱ and mathematically expressed as [2], (10) ϱ = T × ( max m ∈ M , t d ∈ T ( E a m , t d ) ) E τ 3.4 User comfort level The waiting time is greatly subjective to the preferences and comfort levels of end-users. If a consumer wants to switch on a certain household irrespective of SECO-generated schedules, then he/she has to wait after instigating an interrupt, then this delay is counted as a waiting time [2]. For the maximization of consumer satisfaction, the waiting time must be kept low at optimally low electricity bills. In some cases, this delay is high due to the SECO operational schedule in which high power rating appliances are planned to switch on in off-peak hours. Furthermore, if a consumer wants to turn on an appliance without compromising on comfort level, then a high priority will be assigned to that specific appliance in ES so that it could be run in the leading available time slot. In such a situation, the consumer has to pay some penalty, therefore, there is a trade-off between electricity cost and waiting time [12]. This problem is addressed in the second layer of IEMS where the appliance’s operation start and end time is α a m < β a m and t r is the interrupt generation time for the desired appliance. Thus, the waiting time ς r equation can be formulated as, (11) ς r = | t r − α a m | ( β a m − ℓ a m ) − α a m The average waiting time ς r a v g of all appliances is calculated by the following formula. (12) ς r a v g = ∑ m = 1 M | t r − α a m | A 3.5 Tariff rate model The tariff rate is a dynamic attribute offered by power utilities to encourage consumers’ participation in LM strategies according to their preferences. In this work, time of use (ToU) tariff rates and power-dependent inclined block rates (IBR) models are adopted. The ToU model offers different electricity prices for each time slot of a day, whereas, the IBR model restricts consumers within pre-defined blocks of the electricity cost budget. The net electricity purchase price for a day is expressed by, (13) Δ τ p u r = ∑ d = 1 D λ t d × E τ Here, λ t d and Δ τ p u r represent ToU tariff rates (provided by the power utility) and aggregated electricity cost for a day, respectively. Furthermore, the two-block IBR model is formulated using a linear piecewise function in order to penalize consumers, if their energy utilization exceeds the limits of electricity purchase price budget blocks. Following is the mathematical model for two blocks IBR [2], (14) Δ τ p u r = Δ τ p u r 1 E τ 1 < E τ < E τ 2 Δ τ p u r 2 E τ > E τ 2 where Δ τ p u r 1 and Δ τ p u r 2 are first and second budge blocks and E τ 1 and E τ 2 are upper and lower limits on E τ , respectively. Moreover, prosumers can make energy transactions by selling their surplus power to the main grid by obeying utility agreements. According to [40], the selling price is taken as 90% of the electricity purchase price in each hour and mathematically defined as, (15) Δ τ s e l = 0 . 9 × Δ τ p u r 3.6 0 − 1 multiple knapsack problem (MKP) The 0 − 1 MKP is one of the extensions of the KP deterministic approach that can be significantly applied for binary combinatorial resource allocation NP-hard optimization problems. In MKP, each object has a definite weight and value, the decision-makers select certain objects that can be packed in multiple sacks with diverse capacities to maximize their aggregated profit under the set of time/cost constraints [2]. To mitigate the peak formation issue in any time slot, the 0 − 1 MKP approach is implemented to impose bounds on the total energy consumption level in each hour of the day. The SECO-generated operational schedule for a day must satisfy the power capacity aforementioned constraint. In our IEMS model, m k p sacks symbolize time slots in T , n k p objects represent smart appliances in A , w k p object’s weights indicate ρ a m , v k p object’s value signify Δ τ p u r , x k p object’s state specify ψ and sack’s capacities denote consumed energy for each time slot. Thus, the cumulative power equation can be reformulated as, (16) max ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = 1 D E ( a m , t d ) × ψ ( a m , t d ) Subject to: (16a) ∑ d = 1 D Δ τ p u r × ψ ( a m , t d ) ≤ Δ ∀ ψ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] 3.7 Domestic users In our system model, domestic users are categorized into two main groups: active energy users (AEUs) and prosumers (PEUs) based on users’ participation in DSM programs. The AEU only consumes the power supplied by the power grid (either MG and/or SG) and is unable to harvest energy from any RES unit. With the aid of IEMS, they can only shift their load from high to low peak hours for the electricity bill reduction. The AEU set is epitomized by U a = [ U 1 a , U 2 a , U 3 a , … , U N a ] and their aggregated power consumption E T a is determined by, (17) E T a = ∑ n = 1 N ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = 1 D E U n a ( a m , t d ) On the other hand, PEUs generate their own energy through rooftop-PV MGs and utilize both PV-harvested and main grid (either MG and/or SG) power. Such users secure several benefits from the power utility in terms of electricity bill reduction and energy trading schemes. Their set is symbolized by U p = [ U 1 p , U 2 p , U 3 p , … , U N p ] , whereas, their gross power usage E T p is estimated through, (18) E T p = ∑ n = 1 N ∑ m = 1 M ∑ d = 1 D ( E U n p ( a m , t d ) − E ħ ( t d ) − E δ ( t d ) ) All smart residential users or homes are defined by H ∈ [ U a ∪ U p ] and their categorization is depicted in Fig. 5. 3.8 Day-ahead IEMS The scheduling optimization problem is addressed in the first layer of IEMS to accomplish the core objectives of optimal power consumption, peak load shaving, and electricity cost reduction by preserving the power supply and demand balance. Constraints (19)a–(19)e are bounds on the power generated from thermal units, (19)f shows the total power consumption of all appliances, (19)g defines limits on the power produced from PV panels, (19)h–(19)j characterizes the charging status of ESBs, (19)k is the waiting time constraint, (19)l describes the energy transaction mechanism, and (19)m is the 0 − 1 MKP constraint. 3.9 Real-time IEMS The real-time coordination problem among smart appliances, multiple MGs, and the central power grid is taken into account in the second layer of IEMS. Here, the consumer can intrude on any scheduled appliance for the desired appliance execution by generating interrupts. These interrupts enforce the SECO to reschedule the preferred appliance without degrading the system’s performance and effectively reducing the user’s waiting time. (20), it is depicted that if the consumer generates an interrupt I ˆ , it will turned-off the appliance ( 0 denotes the appliance switch-off status), otherwise, the running state of an appliance (symbolizes by 1 ) will remains to continue without any disturbance. Thus, in our model, interrupts are generated to terminate the operation of a particular scheduled appliance. The first option leads to the exact algorithm which solves the optimization problems to their optimality at the cost of execution time (exponentially increases with the increase in problem size). Moreover, the second option urges towards heuristic algorithms that can evaluate NP-hard optimization problems in a quicker and more efficient manner by forfeiting on precision [2]. Stemmed from the stated discussion, three heuristic algorithms have been chosen and modified in our proposed methodology to determine optimal solutions for the NP-hard scheduling problem. In this section, GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS are introduced to elucidate formulated problem formulation. Table 2 enlist all parameters and their values of the three aforementioned IEMSs. 4.1 GA-IEMS The GA algorithm is an artificially intelligent search heuristic algorithm used for the NP-hard optimization problems to find the global minima [6,42]. Basically, it has five fundamental phases: initialize random population, evaluate fitness function, selection scheme, crossover, and mutation to evaluate any optimization problem within the feasible polynomial time. Herein, the original GA is modified according to our system model for the estimation of IEMS’s optimization problems as shown in Algorithm 1. In projected GA-IEMS, the space search is started with an arbitrarily initialized population comprised of binary chromosomes with length L . Each gene in a chromosome represents the binary status of an appliance at a certain time slot. Thus, a randomly generated group of chromosomes acts as an initial population that defines the initial operational behaviors of the set A . Moreover, After the population generation, the fitness function P 1 is evaluated using Eq. (19) for all potential solutions. Then, the roulette spin selected method is executed to avoid repetition in the sequence of genes (bits) in each chromosome. After that, two chromosome pairs are nominated on the basis of their fitness scores for reproduction. For the reproduction phase, crossover p c and mutation p m genetic operators are applied. In the crossover, chosen pairs mate at a random crossover point within chromosomes. Some of the bits are exchanged in the mutation stage to maintain the new population’s diversity and avoid pre-convergence. By observing the termination criteria (maximum number of iterations), the algorithm terminates and globally optimal solutions are achieved. Furthermore, when a user generates an interrupt, the real-time rescheduling problem is solved by repeating the aforesaid steps for the P 2 in Eq. (21). 4.2 WDO-IEMS One of the population-based evolutionary approaches, the WDO algorithm is precisely described in this part. It is a wind atmospheric motion-inspired algorithm with ease of implementation and exceptional convergence properties [43]. At the first stage, an initial population (with size “popsize”) is randomly generated according to newton’s second law of motion, which is comprised of infinitesimally small air parcels navigating over an n th-dimensional search space. Furthermore, each air parcel consists of a binary sequence for status strings of smart appliances with initial velocity v i (m/s) and position x i ( m ). In comparison to the PSO algorithm, the terms for gravitation and coriolis forces have been added to the velocity update equation in order to modify the robustness and flexibility of the algorithm. Herein, the v i is calculated by Eq. (22) [43]. (22) v i = v m a x × 2 × ( r a n d ( p o p s i z e , n c ) − 0 . 5 ) Here, v m a x and n c are the maximum velocity of air parcels in m/s and the total quantity of air parcels, respectively. Furthermore, the fitness of each air parcel in the initial population is assessed by P 1 to acquire relatively best air parcels by neglecting bad ones. In each iteration, the velocity and position equations are updated to assign new values to air parcels. Thus, the equation for v n e w is expressed by Eq. (23) [43]. (23) v n e w = ( 1 − α c ) v i − g x i + [ | P r m a x P r i | R T w ( x m a x − x i ) ] − c v i P r i Subject to: (23a) v n e w = v m a x i f v n e w > v m a x ∀ t d ∈ T , a m ∈ A (23b) v n e w = v m i n i f v n e w < v m a x ∀ t d ∈ T , a m ∈ A where v n e w is reliant on v i , x i , initial pressure P r i ( Pa ), maximum pressure P r m a x ( Pa ), maximum distance from the uppermost pressure point x m a x ( m ), temperature T w ( ∘ C ), gravitational acceleration g ( N ), and the constants (R, α c , and c). Moreover, ( 1 − α c ) v i , g x i , c v i P r i , and | P r m a x P r i | R T ( x m a x − x i ) constitutes opposing forces, gravitational force, coriolis forces, and factor for air parcel’s motion towards its global best position. Whereas, (23)a and (23)b are upper v m a x and lower v m i n limits on the air parcel’s velocity. The equation for the air parcel’s new position is, (24) x n e w = x i + ( v n e w × Δ c t d ) In Eq. (23), the value of stepsize Δ c is 1 h . Furthermore, the new generation is obtained by updating the air parcel’s positions and velocities equations in each iteration till the stopping criterion (maximum iterations). In case of interrupts, the new generation that is consisted of optimal operational schedules for each household is reevaluated by fitness function P 2 in Eq. (21). All the comprehensive steps for WDO-IEMS are signified in Algorithm 2. 4.3 HGW-IEMS Although the performance of GA and WDO algorithms are quite satisfactory for NP-hard multi-dimensional optimization problems, they often exhibit pre-mature convergence and high computational complexity [6,43]. In recent literature, various hybrid heuristic algorithms have been developed to tackle aforesaid issues in optimization algorithms of real-world problems [22,29]. In this context, an amalgamation of GA and WDO as a hybrid optimization algorithm is introduced to obviate pre-mature convergence and computational burden issues. The HGW-IEMS permits both explicit algorithms to give their full play according to respective merit such as GA empowers WDO by preserving population diversity through genetic parameters ( p c and p m ), an effective method to deal with the local optimum in WDO. Additionally, the WDO’s convergence factor aids to resolve the limitations of GA. The meticulous steps for HGW-IEMS are stated in Algorithm 3. Here, all WDO algorithm phases are executed as defined in earlier parts, whereas, its velocity updating equation is replaced by crossover and mutation. The reason to do so is in some cases, air pressure values become extremely large, causing the velocity up-gradation to become a lengthy procedure that degrades the WDO algorithm performance. Furthermore, a roulette spin selection method is employed to maintain population diversity in the air parcel’s population and the fitness of each parcel is evaluated by P 1 in Eq. (19). The position of air parcels is updated by Eq. (24). This process will be recursively persistent till the pre-defined termination criterion (maximum iterations). Moreover, rescheduling of the priority household is done by estimating fitness function P 2 in Eq. (21) and repeating the entire aforementioned procedure. 5 Numerical analysis Extensive simulations have been carried out to evaluate and validate proposed double-layer IEMS through MATLAB 2018 a and PVSyst 7.0 software on the system with specifications: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7 CPU @ 2.80 GHz and 8 GB RAM. To tackle the randomness factor in optimal solutions acquired from the proposed methodology, the MCS approach is performed by taking an average of ten iterations. Furthermore, the ToU tariff model offered by Jemena electricity networks is considered for a residential area comprised of over 343 k customers (smart homes) and several small-scale businesses that are connected to approximately 6 , 160 km extended electricity distribution system and occupy over 950 km 2 of area located in the northwest greater Melbourne, Australia [44]. According to [44], the electricity price of a day is divided into three units rate dependent on the power demand as in Fig. 6. The off-peak unit rate is 3.836¢ / kWh for time slots of 10 pm to 7 am, shoulder unit rate is 8.587¢ / kWh in the time periods of 7 am to 3 pm and 9 pm to 10 pm for weekdays, while 7 am to 10 pm for weekends, and peak unit rate is 12.642¢ / kWh for 3 pm to 9 pm time period. In the IEMS system model, each smart home is equipped with various virtually interconnected smart electric households. To drive numerical analysis for multi- and single- objective functions, the input data related to set A is collected from the user interface in a day-head routine. In our scenario, the selection of appliances has been done on the basis of their usage in all seasons, while the entire gathered information is tabulated in Table 3 to highlight categories and pre-defined parameters (power ratings and operational time period) of each elected appliance. The PVSyst software is used to examine the presented roof-top PV-based MG model. Through it, all the meteorological statistics of the Melbourne MeteoNorm 7.2 station, Australia imported from the national aeronautics and space administration (NASA) is attained by setting parameters at latitude ( 37 . 82 ° south), longitude ( 144 . 97 ° east), and altitude 113 m above sea level. Herein, mono-crystalline plates with a cross-sectional area of 75 m 2 and tilted angle of 35 ° are implanted for each smart user. This type of plate has much higher efficiency (about ( 87 % ) ) and power generation capacity as compared to other PV plate types with 1% annual degradation [45]. Figs. 7 and 8 depict solar paths and irradiance patterns for a day at the aforesaid location, respectively. By using Hanwha Q cells manufactured panels with the ventilation system, about 18 . 1 MWh of the gross energy can be yielded at the expenditure of 40309 € . By employing values of T p ( t d ) from [46] in Eq. (6), the output power from the PV system for a day is calculated. Furthermore, 90% out of net harvested power in each time slot is available for PEU usage to deal with the unpredictable nature of the sun (ambiguities between expected and actual power). To charge the storage unit connected with the PV panel, 40% out of 90% PV-harvested power is utilized (charging level can vary 10% to 90% of RES’s energy) as demonstrated in Fig. 9. 5.1 Day-ahead IEMS In this part, the performance of the first layer in day-ahead IEMS is reconnoitered for both AEUs and PEUs. For AEUs, all modified heuristic algorithms are executed in SECO by taking into consideration assumptions in AEU’s system model for the evaluation of the P 1 , while their results in terms of energy consumption, electricity cost, and PAR patterns are revealed in Figs. 10, Fig. 11, and Fig. 12, respectively. It is noteworthy that the proposed heuristic-based methodologies show significantly optimal outcomes for our system model. As compared to GA-IEMS and WDO-IEMS, the hybrid HGW-IEMS outperforms concerning both optimality and robustness. Furthermore, GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS avoid peak formation in any time slot of a day due to the application of 0 − 1 MKP, as a consequence, the electricity bill is automatically decreased. Besides it, the HGW-IEMS model attained robust optimal solutions within less convergence time and high precision because of the merged genetic operators. The best outcomes from the WDO-IEMS are also within the feasible region, however, its performance is compromised owing to the extremely large pressure values. From Fig. 12, it is clear that the PAR is minimized about 45% in the case of HGW-IEMS, 26% in GA-IEMS, and 9% in WDO-IEMS as compared to unscheduled load (None-IEMS). There are many opportunities for PEUs to earn profits from power utilities in comparison to AEUs by virtue of roof-top PV MGs with integrated ESB. Each PEU can shift as much of its electric load on the PV-generated power through a day as reserve power is available by following defined constraints in our system model. To corroborate the formulated objective function for PEU, models for PV panels and storage units (mostly operating in high peak hours and/or at night) are considered during simulations. Attained outcomes with reference to hourly optimal energy consumption, energy cost, and PAR pattern are exhibited in Figs. 13, Fig. 14, and Fig. 15. It is prominent that the maximum estimated energy consumption for unscheduled load is 21.69 kWh, whereas, in GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS, its value is calculated as 6.04 kWh, 9.09 kWh, and 4.60 kWh, respectively. In addition to it, achieved percentage reductions in electricity cost are 35%, 15%, and 73% and PAR is declined up to 41%, 36%, and 74% for GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS, respectively. Furthermore, feasible regions (sets of points defining possible optimal solutions) can be calculated for GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS in order to validate the results of proposed optimization methodologies by considering AEUs and PEUs. Due to the limitation of space, outcomes of HGW-IEMS for AEU are given in Fig. 16 for a graphical description of the direct relationship between load and electricity cost. Here, the area bounded by four points: P 1 ( 8 . 7669 , 37 . 6658 ) , P 2 ( 8 . 7669 , 72 . 4731 ) , P 4 ( 22 . 2567 , 81 . 5407 ) , and P 3 ( 22 . 2567 , 248 . 7200 ) is representing a feasible area, whereas, points P 5 ( 22 . 2567 , 220 . 5967 ) and P 6 ( 19 . 5230 , 220 . 5967 ) are maximum bounds on the power consumption cost. Besides it, optimal results of all heuristic models are within the generated green area, thus verifying their optimality. 5.2 Real-time IEMS In the second layer of IEMS, the real-time rescheduling problem is evaluated to determine the user comfort level by randomly generating interrupts in the real-time scenario and estimates P 2 . Fig. 17 illustrates the performance of GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS with respect to waiting times of interruptible appliances. It is evidently seen, the waiting time for the coffee maker (CM), microwave oven (MO), electric kettle (EK), and vacuum cleaner (VC) obeys the designed constraint. (19)k. Through the coordination between the user interface and IEMS, the SECO monitors the system to check the operational feasibility of the consumer’s interrupt and decides either to turn off the scheduled appliance (s) during their operational period (s) or commands users to guard them against the utility’s penalty. In this work, HGW-IEMS performance is much better as compared to other models in both coordinated and non-coordinated scenarios. However, any further interrupts could penalize the end-users according to the IBR cost model. 5.3 Cases In the following part, we have further reconnoitered our formulated IEMS system model for two cases. 5.3.1 Case 1: Single home Herein, a detailed numerical analysis has been performed to acquire optimal outcomes of data-driven double-layer IEMS for a smart home in the domestic area linked with a decentralized power distribution system. All results are summarized in the Table 4 for a week (with five weekdays and two weekends) to estimate monthly electricity bills (for consumers) and PAR (for power utility). It can easily be envisioned that the HGW-IEMS performed more effectively as compared to others with respect to energy consumption (kWh), electricity costs (AUD), PAR, and waiting time (h). By taking into account stated values, the monthly electricity bill can be estimated for both AEU and PEU. For instance, the estimated monthly electricity cost of an AEU in the month of M a y decrements from 193 . 7 $ to 144 . 6 $ , 164 . 4 $ , and 90 . 0 $ and PAR percentage reduction is 52%, 34%, and 72% using GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS, respectively. Similarly, the calculated electricity bill of a PEU in the month of M a y is further decreased to 117 . 7 $ , 129 . 0 $ , and 44 . 8 $ and percentage PAR reduction is 62%, 40%, and 84% by engaging PV panel in GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS, respectively. Furthermore, this PEU also has surplus energy to sell at the cost of 62 . 3 $ when participating in energy trading schemes. Hence, it can be deduced that each heuristic-based system follows all the constraints of P 1 and P 1 , ominously reduces the energy cost, and acts as greatly efficient techniques to tackle peak formation problems. 5.3.2 Case 2: Multiple homes To examine the efficiency of proposed IEMS for a large number of users, multiple smart homes (for the sake of simulations, 5, 50, and 100 smart homes are considered in this paper) in a smart residential area (Fig. 3) are taken into account. During simulations, Melbourne’s weather is divided into two major seasons i.e. summer (December ∼ May) and winter (June ∼ November). All the outcomes are recapitulated in the Table 5 for energy consumption, electricity bills, PAR, and waiting time factors. It is noteworthy, the HGW-IEMS acts as the most appropriate solution even for multiple smart homes, while the performance trend is HGW-IEMS > GA-IEMS > WDO-IEMS for all sets of homes. Furthermore, the annual percentage reduction in the case of 5 smart homes for electricity bills is 63%, 54%, and 74% and PAR is 60%, 46%, and 76% with the conspicuous decline in waiting times is achieved from GA-IEMS, WDO-IEMS, and HGW-IEMS, respectively. Additionally, the stored surplus energy cost for 5 , 50 , and 100 homes is 933 . 15 kWh , 10218 kWh , and 20050 kWh , respectively. With the increase in the number of smart homes, energy utilization is also amplified, but these attained patterns will remain the same. Hence, the IEMS’s system model is cost-effective and highly beneficial for power stability, while the HGW-IEMS is the most suitable LM system in terms of both electricity cost and PAR reduction, and could be significantly employed for practical LM programs. 5.4 Energy trading The impact of roof-top PV MGs on the electric market is inspected to promote energy trading schemes in decentralized power systems. In this work, a domestic area with four interconnected MGs is deliberated for the energy transaction analysis. Herein, each MG has generation units (fossil fuel, natural gas, and PV panels), adequate storage units, and a remote flexible load. The dis/charging of storage units is a function of harvested power, maximum power demand, and high tariff rates at any hour of the day as expressed in Eq. (7), the resultant dis/charging patterns of four Lithium-ion batteries are shown in Fig. 19. All batteries are charged in time intervals when PV panel-based MG has a surplus amount of harvested power and/or in the presence of solar radiance (indicated by + v e values), while discharge if any MG becomes energy deficit (needs the power to fulfill the load demand) and/or in the night time (symbolized by − v e values). The gross cost of net non-renewable power in each MG is acquired from Eq. (9) by taking values of a g n , b g n , and c g n from [2]. Moreover, the PV panel installment cost is greatly reliant on the prosumer’s requirement, while its running cost is assumed to be zero. The lower and upper power generation bounds are flexible and depend on the optimal scheduling of participating generators obtained through the LP method. In Fig. 18, the box plot expresses generated power ranges, while step plots depict consumed energy patterns in each hour of the day. The performances of M G 1 , M G 2 , M G 3 , and M G 4 are exhibited in Fig. 18(a), Fig. 18(b), Fig. 18(c), and Fig. 18(d), respectively. From the results, it is clear that the proposed methodologies effectively optimize energy consumption patterns by satisfying power generation capacities. The rated stored power and imbalance between supply and demand are decisive parameters on which each MG controller takes energy trading decisions to meet load demand and earn revenue. The electricity export and import rates are determined by Eq. (15) and Eq. (13), respectively. Then, the net monthly electricity bills for each MG are revealed in Fig. 20 to illustrate the earned profit. It is clearly verified that the proposed system model is beneficial to earn revenues from the power utilities and the net profit is increased with the increase in the number of MG. 6 Conclusion The data-driven heuristic algorithm-based optimization methodology is proposed for the residential IEMSs by considering the smart power grid’s reliability and economic criteria. In this work, the MILP and 0 − 1 MKP methods are employed for the reliable mathematical formulations of the electric load scheduling and management problems to accomplish objectives of electricity bill minimization, PAR reduction, smart appliance’s optimized operational times, pecuniary dis/charging patterns of ESBs, and proficient energy transaction mechanism for the residential area. The designed multi- and single- objective optimization functions for the multi-dimensional NP-hard day-ahead scheduling problem (dealt with in the first layer of IEMS) and real-time coordination problem (addressed in the second layer of IEMS) provide system operational efficiency and reliability. Furthermore, a comprehensive numerical analysis has been done to corroborate the effectiveness of the presented heuristic algorithm-based IEMSs in a comparative manner. Simulation results reveal that the HGW-IEMS outperformed GA-IEMS and WDO-IEMS in terms of energy consumption, electricity cost, PAR, and user comfort level. Among these models, WDO-IEMS has the highest execution time owing to the large pressure values in the velocity updating equation caused by the complex environment of focused load scheduling problems with gigantic attributes. It is also deduced that the energy cost in the case of PEUs is significantly decreased due to roof-top PV panels as compared to AEUs. Besides it, the proposed models can be significantly applied to energy trading schemes in order to facilitate end-users and power utilities in the distributed power system. On the other hand, the proposed methodology has severe limitations regarding the computational burden such as the system’s memory size and operational power in the case of real-time bi-directional data and power flow. Motivated by critical research problems in modern power system studies, our future directions will be (1.) implementation of uncertainty modeling techniques to hedge against uncertain input parameters in LM problems, (2.) optimal allocation of smart charging stations for EVs, and (3.) designing of RES-based charging stations to provide an eco-friendly environment. coredata.dc:description: Energy management techniques have been immensely adopted in residential, industrial, and commercial sectors to meritoriously flatten the load profile of consumers. In this article, a cutting-edge intelligent energy management system is proposed to analytically monitor and regulate the load demand of a residential area to meritoriously address the load balancing and scheduling optimization problem with an aim to design an autonomous domestic complex, less reliant on the focal power grid. To do so, single- and multi- objective functions are defined for the presented double-layered framework. In the first layer, a day-ahead scheduling problem is evaluated to achieve the mutual revenue of electricity utilities and consumers, while in the second layer, a real-time coordination scheme for robust energy transactions among appliances, multiple microgrids, and the main power system is examined. Herein, a 0 − 1 multiple knapsack problem incorporated with the mixed-integer linear programming method is used to formulate the system mathematical model. To evaluate the intended system model, three heuristic algorithms (genetic algorithm, wind-driven optimization, and their hybrid) are modified. Furthermore, the Monte–Carlo simulations are performed to mitigate the impact of randomness and avoid pre-convergence. From the results of extensive simulations, it is corroborated that the proposed methodology is robust, reliable, and eco-social compared to prior schemes. This article reveals that the hybrid approach outperformed the other two strategies in terms of energy consumption, electricity cost, peak-to-average ratio, and user comfort level.
coredata.dc:title: Data-driven multi-layered intelligent energy management system for domestic decentralized power distribution systems
